name: The Scribe Candle-Clock Figure
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To indicate the passage of time.
agency: A scribe rotates, pointing to time divisions, and a falcon drops a ball.
design: As the candle burns and rises, a string connected to the counterweight turns a pulley, which rotates the scribe. The rising candle mechanism also lifts a ball channel to release balls to the falcon.
citations: a dais with a scribe on it, having a pen in his hand, which is on the fifteen divisions of a complete circle
The scribe's pen moves until its tip is opposite the first mark... When the pen has reached the end of 15 degrees the falcon drops a ball
shortQuote: a scribe on it, having a pen in his hand

name: The Drummers' Water-Clock Figures
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To signal the hour with a musical performance.
agency: A full band of seven musicians plays instruments, a man moves along a battlement, and a falcon drops a ball.
design: A tipping bucket fills and empties every hour, turning a water wheel with pegs that operate the musicians' arms via levers. Air displaced from a vessel blows the trumpets. A float system moves the man along the frieze.
citations: On this platform are seven men: on the right two blowing trumpets, on the left two playing cymbals - the rest are drummers.
The middle one has two kettle-drums... while the two to his left and right each has a drum slung over his shoulder
at daybreak the man is at the end of the frieze and moves smoothly until he is behind the first of the twelve battlements
the falcon leans forward and casts a ball from its beak onto the cymbal in the vase, and the musicians play.
shortQuote: the falcon leans forward and the musicians play

name: The Monkey Candle-Clock Figures
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To indicate the passage of time.
agency: A monkey figure rises up a pole, pointing to time markings, while a keeper figure appears to hold the pole.
design: As the candle burns, the counterweight drops. A string connects the weight to the monkey's post, pulling it upward along a graduated scale.
citations: a man kneeling on his right knee... On his shoulder is a short post which he holds with his right hand.
On top of the post is a disc upon which is a sitting monkey... Its right paw is outstretched, and the index finger is on one of the points
The monkey's keeper lifts the monkey up the post gradually
shortQuote: index finger is on one of the points

name: The Castle Water-Clock Figures
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To announce the passage of hours through movement and sound.
agency: The figures appear to play instruments and emerge from doors autonomously at specific time intervals.
appearance: A large architectural facade featuring doors, falcons in niches, and a band of musicians (drummers, trumpeters, cymbalist) at the base.
design: Driven by a water reservoir and float system. As the float sinks, it pulls a cart that triggers the doors and falcons. The musicians are powered by a water wheel with pegs that strike levers connected to their arms, while air forced from a vessel sounds the trumpets.
citations: Below the wall several figures are situated - two drummers, two trumpeters and a cymbalist.
the two panels of the first of the upper doors open and a figure, made according to the choice of the craftsman, comes out and stands as if he had suddenly emerged.
the two birds lean forward until they approach the two two vases, and two balls are dropped from their beaks, each on to a cymbal
the drummers drum, the trumpeters blow and the cymbalist plays his cymbals for a while.
shortQuote: the drummers drum, the trumpeters blow and the cymbalist plays

name: The Peacock Water-Clock Figures
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To signal the passage of time through animal behavior.
agency: A peacock turns, chicks squabble, and a peahen moves from side to side.
design: Water flows into a tipping bucket. When it tips, it turns a ratchet wheel that moves the peahen. The water then flows over a scoop wheel which drives gears to turn the peacock and operates levers to make the chicks peck.
citations: on the ball is a peacock... His tail is erect and spread out as if he is making a display.
two young peacocks, each standing on one side of the mihrab as if they are quarreling.
a peahen... Her neck and beak are stretched out towards the right hand pillar... Then she turns away from it towards her left
shortQuote: two young peacocks standing as if they are quarreling

name: The Candle-Clock of the Doors Figures
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To signal the hour visually.
agency: Figures emerge from doors every hour.
design: A rotating rod with a projection turns with the main pulley mechanism. As it passes each door, it unhooks a catch, allowing a weighted figure to fall forward and push the doors open.
citations: When a constant hour has passed... the door opposite the falcon opens, and a figure emerges
At the second hour the second door opens... and so on
shortQuote: a figure emerges when a constant hour has passed

name: The Elephant Water-Clock Figures
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To announce the half-hour and hour with elaborate movements and sounds.
agency: A scribe rotates, a bird whistles, a man on a balcony moves his hands, falcons drop balls, serpents swallow the balls, and a mahout strikes the elephant.
design: Powered by a sinking float in the elephant's belly. As it sinks, it pulls chains that rotate the scribe and release balls. The balls trigger the serpents and the balcony man. The mahout is driven by a lever system activated by the falling balls.
citations: It is a complete elephant, with a man mounted between its shoulders, like a mahout.
In his right hand is an axe... and in his left hand is a mallet
A man sits on this balcony... The man sitting on the balcony is tilted over on his right thigh and his right hand is placed on the beak of the right-hand falcon
The bird whistles on top of the cupola and rotates
With his right hand the mahout gives the head of the elephant one blow with the axe... and raises his left hand, with the mallet in it, and strikes the head of the elephant with it.
shortQuote: The bird whistles on top of the cupola and rotates

name: The Beaker Water-Clock Scribe
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To indicate the passage of minutes and hours.
agency: A scribe figure rotates slowly, pointing with a pen to time graduations on a ring.
design: A float inside the beaker sinks as water drips out. A chain attached to the float turns a pulley, which rotates the vertical axle holding the scribe.
citations: On the cover is a bench upon which is a scribe holding a pen, its tip on the ring outside the first division.
This moves with a regular, almost imperceptible motion... until the tip of the pen reaches the first division
shortQuote: a scribe holding a pen, its tip on the ring

name: The Swordsman Candle-Clock Figures
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To trim the candle wick and signal the hour.
agency: A falcon drops a ball and a slave strikes the candle wick with a sword to trim it.
design: As the candle burns, a weight pushes it up. Balls are released from a magazine. The falling ball hits a pouch connected to the slave's arm, causing the sword to strike. The ball then rolls out through the falcon's beak.
citations: Near its foot is a falcon... Towards the top of the sheath is a bracket... and on this is a black slave.
In his right hand is a sword... the falcon lets fall a ball from its beak... and the slave strikes the wick with his sword, removing the portion that has burned away
shortQuote: slave strikes the wick with his sword

name: The Boat Water-Clock Figures
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To track time and signal the hour.
agency: A scribe writes/points to time divisions, a falcon drops a ball, and a serpent swallows the ball and bows down to drop it onto a cymbal.
design: A sinking float (tarjahar) pulls a chain that rotates the scribe. When the float sinks completely, it triggers a ball release. The ball falls into a balanced serpent's mouth, weighing it down; as the serpent tips, it pulls the float up, emptying it to restart the cycle.
citations: On the dome is a platform upon which sits a man with a pen in his hand.
the falcon lets fall from its beak a solid ball... into the mouth of the serpent.
The head [of the serpent] rotates and sinks slowly until it reaches the bow of the boat; it casts the ball on to a cymbal... The serpent now rises back to its original position.
shortQuote: The serpent now rises back to its original position.

name: The Boon-Companion
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To drink wine left in goblets and eventually soak a guest as a prank.
agency: The figure raises a goblet to its mouth, nods its head, and moves its left hand.
design: Wine poured into the goblet flows into a reservoir inside the figure. A siphon and float mechanism controls the arm movement. The head is balanced to nod when the weight distribution changes.
citations: It is a kneeling figure... He holds a goblet in his right hand... and in his left hand he holds a waterlily
he lifts the goblet in his hand until its rim is between his lips [where it stays] for a while. Then he lowers the goblet... and nods his head several times.
His left hand moves... until after a while it reaches a certain position.
shortQuote: lifts the goblet until its rim is between his lips

name: The Arbitrating Goblet Bird
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To select a drinker at a party randomly.
agency: A bird rotates, whistles, and stops pointing at a specific person.
design: Wine poured over the lid drives a small impeller (water-wheel) inside. The impeller turns the bird. Air displaced by the entering wine is forced through a whistle.
citations: In the centre of the lid is a beautiful dome on top of which is a bird with an open beak.
The bird rotates and the whistle emits a shrill tone... The bird comes to rest and stops whistling; its head is pointed towards one of the party
shortQuote: The bird comes to rest and stops whistling

name: The Slave-Girl from the Cupboard
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To serve wine at intervals.
agency: A figure emerges from a cupboard offering wine and retreats when the door is closed.
design: The figure is mounted on a wheeled board on a slope. A mechanism holds her back until a tipping bucket fills the glass in her hand. The weight releases a catch, and she rolls forward pushing the doors open.
citations: the leaves open on a slave girl standing in the door holding in her right hand a glass filled with wine
The king takes the glass... Then he closes the [door] leaves on her.
After an eighth of an hour the leaves open [again] and the slave girl emerges holding the glass.
shortQuote: a slave girl standing in the door holding wine

name: The Man with Goblet and Bottle
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To simulate drinking wine.
agency: A figure pours wine from a bottle to a goblet and raises the goblet to its mouth.
design: Wine flows from a reservoir in the head to the bottle, then to the goblet. The goblet arm is counterweighted; as the goblet fills, it becomes heavy and sinks (or rises depending on the linkage described), eventually siphoning the wine into a hidden tank.
citations: a standing slave holding a silver goblet in his right hand... In his left hand is a bottle
wine flows from the bottle into the goblet. He lifts his right hand with the glass in it to his mouth... for a while as if drinking
shortQuote: lifts his right hand with the glass to his mouth

name: The Two Shaykhs
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To simulate two men drinking together.
agency: Two figures take turns pouring wine for each other and drinking it.
design: A reservoir drips water into a tilting channel that directs flow alternately to two tipping buckets. These buckets trigger the flow of wine to the bottles. The drinking arm motion is driven by the weight of the filling goblet and a siphon mechanism.
citations: two old men facing each other. Each one holds a goblet... and a bottle
one of the shaykhs pours wine from his bottle into his friend's goblet. His friend drinks it and nods his head several times.
the other shaykh pours wine... His friend drinks it and nods his head
shortQuote: pours wine from his bottle into his friend's goblet

name: The Boat Automaton Figures
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To entertain guests at a drinking party on a pool.
agency: Sailors row the boat, and a band of musicians plays instruments at intervals.
design: A reservoir in the boat drips water into a tipping bucket. The bucket dumps water over a scoop wheel, which turns cams to move the musicians' arms. The water then displaces air to blow a flute. The rowing mechanism is less clearly defined but linked to the movement.
citations: the seated figure of the king... a slave holding a jug and goblet... a group of boon-companions
a flute-player, a harpist and then a tambourine-player.
a standing sailor, holding the boat's rudder. On either gunwale of the boat is a sailor holding an oar.
the sailors move... and the oars move it [the boat] through the water
the flute player blows the flute and the [other] slave-girls play their instruments
shortQuote: the sailors move and the oars move the boat

name: The Standing Cup-Bearer
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To serve wine automatically.
agency: A slave figure pours wine from a fish into a glass and lowers the glass to be taken.
design: Wine drips from a reservoir in the figure's chest into a tipping bucket. The bucket dumps wine into the fish (held in the left hand), making it heavy so it tilts. The wine flows into the glass (held in the right hand), making the arm heavy so it lowers.
citations: He is a standing slave... In his right hand is a glass... His left hand... holds a silver fish.
the head of the fish tilts until it is near the glass, and clarified wine flows from its mouth into the glass
Then its head lifts and the slave's hand with the glass sinks
shortQuote: the slave's hand with the glass sinks

name: The Hand-Washing Peacock
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To pour water for washing.
agency: A peacock statue pours water from its beak.
design: The peacock's tail contains a reservoir with a valve. When the valve is opened (via a ring on the tail), water flows into the body, rises to the top of a siphon in the neck, and discharges through the beak.
citations: It is a peacock... Its neck is erect with the head lowered, its beak extended and open
Water pours from its beak... while [the servant] stands aside.
shortQuote: Water pours from its beak while the servant stands aside

name: The Castle Wine Dispenser Figures
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To entertain and dispense wine at intervals.
agency: A complex scene involving a rotating horseman, a dancer, a band of musicians playing instruments, and a slave girl who pours wine.
design: Wine drips from a reservoir into a tipping bucket. The bucket dumps wine over a scoop wheel which drives the horseman and dancer via gears. Cams on an axle operate the musicians' arms. The wine then flows into the slave girl's bottle, which tilts when full.
citations: On the dais sits a slave-girl... In her right hand she grasps the neck of a bottle... In front of her is a goblet.
four slave girls. One holds a flute... another holds a tambourine, another holds a lute, and the last has a drum
a dancer on a ball... a horse and rider.
the horse and rider rotate slowly... The dancer makes a half turn... The flautist plays... and the slave girls play their instruments
the slave-girl tilts the bottle... and pours... until the goblet is nearly full
shortQuote: the slave-girl tilts the bottle and pours

name: The Two Scribes of the Measuring Basin
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To measure blood volume.
agency: One scribe rotates to point at numbers; the other holds a pen that points to a rising board.
design: Similar to the Monk basin. A float in a central receiver rises with the liquid. It pushes up a graduated board (for the second scribe) and pulls a string to rotate a pulley (for the first scribe).
citations: a platform with two scribes on it. One of them is sitting inside a circle... The other scribe is sitting at the corner... In his left sleeve one can see the end of a board
the pen of the [first] scribe moves to the first number... and the board of the second scribe rises from his sleeve
shortQuote: the pen of the scribe moves to the first number

name: The Hand-Washing Slave
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To pour water for washing and offer drying items.
agency: A figure pours water from a pitcher and then extends a hand offering a towel and comb.
design: Water is poured into a reservoir in the figure. A valve releases it to the pitcher for pouring. A float in the reservoir descends as water is used, eventually triggering a lever that extends the left arm.
citations: It is a slave... holding a pitcher in his outstretched right hand... His left hand is raised... and in the palm of the hand is a towel... a mirror and a comb.
water runs from the spout... When he has finished his ablutions the slave stretches out his left hand until it is straight
shortQuote: the slave stretches out his left hand until it is straight

name: The Monk of the Measuring Basin
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To measure the amount of blood let from a patient.
agency: A monk figure rotates, pointing with a staff to a calibrated scale.
design: Blood flows into a central cylinder containing a float. As the float rises, it pulls a string wrapped around a pulley. The pulley rotates the vertical axle on which the monk stands.
citations: On top of the tower stands a monk holding a staff, with the bottom of the staff on the basin's rim.
When one dirham of blood falls into the bottom of the basin the bottom of the staff moves to the first number
shortQuote: the staff moves to the first number

name: The Castle Basin Figures
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To indicate blood volume.
agency: Doors open to reveal boys indicating numbers, and hands appear in a window.
design: A pulley system driven by a float rotates an axle. A rod on the axle unhooks catches holding the doors, allowing weighted figures to fall forward and open them. A separate ring carrying hands rotates behind the window.
citations: a castle with 12 doors... the leaves of the large door open on a door as large as one of the eleven doors. In it is the figure of a standing boy... his right hand indicating 'ten'.
Above this door is a window... In it is a hand indicating 'ten'
shortQuote: a standing boy... his right hand indicating 'ten'

name: The Bronze Triton Weather Vane
purpose: To indicate the direction of the wind
agency: The figure actively rotates to face the oncoming breeze and points a rod specifically at the representation of the current wind direction.
appearance: A bronze statue of a Triton (a Greek sea god) holding an outstretched rod in its right hand, mounted atop a conical piece of marble on the roof of an octagonal tower.
design: The statue is mounted on a pivot mechanism that allows it to rotate freely with the wind, ensuring the rod aligns with the wind's source to point at reliefs of the winds carved on the tower's sides.
citations: on top of the tower he set a conical shaped piece of marble and on this a bronze Triton with a rod outstretched in its right hand.
It was so contrived as to go round with the wind, always stopping to face the breeze and holding its rod as a pointer directly over the representation of the wind that was blowing.
shortQuote: always stopping to face the breeze and holding its rod

name: The Slave Basin Figures
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To pour water, dispose of used water, and offer drying items.
agency: A slave pours water; a duck drinks the water; the slave offers a towel.
design: Water flows from a reservoir to the pitcher. Used water collects in the basin and is siphoned into a hidden tank (making it look like the duck drinks it). A float in the tank rises, pulling a lever that extends the slave's left arm.
citations: a kneeling slave holding a pitcher in his right hand and a towel and comb in his left
In the floor of the basin is a handsome, crouching duck... the duck drinks it all.
The slave extends his hand with the towel and the comb.
shortQuote: The slave extends his hand with the towel

name: The Cow of the Water-Raising Pool
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To simulate an animal driving a water wheel.
agency: A wooden cow walks in a circle, appearing to drive the machinery.
design: The cow is actually driven by the machinery. Water turns a scoop wheel below the pool, which drives gears that rotate the central pillar and the disc carrying the cow.
citations: On the disc is a wooden cow which moves round and turns a lever-arm on a vertical axle
shortQuote: wooden cow which moves round and turns a lever-arm

name: Ctesibius's Water Clock Figures
purpose: To indicate the time and provide spectacle
agency: Various figures perform actions such as moving, sounding trumpets, dropping objects, and pointing out the specific hour of the day.
appearance: A complex assembly involving revolving cones, falling pebbles or eggs, trumpets, and a specific figure holding a rod that rises from the bottom of the clock to point at a column marked with hours.
design: A regular flow of water raises an inverted bowl (cork or drum) connected to a rack and toothed drum; the engagement of these teeth drives various racks and gears that trigger the mechanical movements and sounds.
citations: figures are moved, cones revolve, pebbles or eggs fall, trumpets sound, and other incidental effects take place.
a figure emerging from the bottom points to them with a rod throughout the whole day.
shortQuote: a figure emerging from the bottom points to them

name: Automaton of Dionysus
source: Book One, Section III.3 (Page 17), Section IV.1-2 (Page 19), Section XIII (Page 45-47)
purpose: To perform libations and rotate
agency: The figure pours liquids (milk/water and wine) from handheld items and physically turns around to face the audience.
appearance: A figurine of the god Dionysus standing in the center of the shrine, holding a thyrsus (staff) and a cup, with a panther at his feet.
design: Pipes run through the figure's body to the cup and thyrsus, connected to hidden containers of liquid controlled by a stopcock (tap) and cords. The rotation is driven by a weight and chain mechanism triggered by the movement of the main shrine.

the figurine of Dionysus will turn towards the outside.

name: The Reckoner of the Measuring Basin
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To indicate blood volume in increments of ten.
agency: A figure (The Reckoner) changes hand gestures to indicate numbers.
design: A rotating vertical wheel inside the fort carries twelve different arms/hands. As the float rises, a pulley system rotates this wheel, displaying the appropriate hand through the window.
citations: a fort (burj) with a door in it in which can be seen the head and the breast of a man.
the man in the fort shows his right arms... the fingers indicating 'ten'.
the man covers the hand which had indicated 'ten' and reveals the one indicating 'twenty'.
shortQuote: the fingers indicating 'ten'

name: The Mobile Shrine of Dionysus
purpose: A self-propelling religious spectacle
agency: The entire shrine moves forward, stops at specific locations, performs a ritual, and returns to its starting point without human intervention.
appearance: A base roughly one cubit long with four columns, an architrave, and a circular shrine with six columns on top. It features a cone-shaped cupola topped with a Nike figure.
design: It uses a system of wheels, axles, and cords connected to a lead counterweight inside a tube filled with millet or mustard seeds. As the grain empties, the weight descends, pulling cords that drive the wheels.

On the covering stands prominently, in the middle, a circular shrine with six columns.
shortQuote: a circular shrine with six columns

name: The Peacock Basin Figures
bookDisplayName: The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices
purpose: To pour water and offer washing items.
agency: A peacock pours water; slaves emerge from doors offering soap and a towel.
design: Water poured into the peacock flows out the beak and into the basin. It drains into a float chamber. As the float rises, it pushes a rod that tilts the first slave figure out the door. Overflow fills a second chamber to trigger the second slave.
citations: On the roof of the castle is a standing peacock... pouring a small quantity of water from its beak
the leaves open on the door at the right... and a slave emerges from it holding a jar containing vegetable soda
the leaves open on the door at the left... and a slave emerges holding a towel
shortQuote: A peacock pouring a small quantity of water from its beak

name: Automaton of Nike
source: Book One, Section III.3 (Page 17), Section IV.2 (Page 19), Section XIII.7-8 (Page 49-51)
purpose: To rotate in sync with the deity
agency: The figure rotates on top of the shrine simultaneously with the Dionysus figure.
appearance: A figure of Victory (Nike) with spread wings, holding a wreath, standing on the peak of the shrine's cupola.
design: Attached to an axle connected to the same mechanism that turns Dionysus; cords and pulleys link her movement to the central pipe rotation driven by a descending weight.
citations: á¼Ï€á½¶ Î´á½² Ï„á¿†Ï‚ ÎºÎ¿ÏÏ…Ï†á¿†Ï‚ á¼Ï†Î­ÏƒÏ„Î·ÎºÎµ ÎÎ¯ÎºÎ· á¼ÎºÏ€ÎµÏ€ÎµÏ„Î±ÎºÏ…á¿–Î± Ï„á½°Ï‚ Ï€Ï„Î­ÏÏ…Î³Î±Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼Î½ Ï„á¿‡ Î´ÎµÎ¾Î¹Ë Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ïá½¶ ÏƒÏ„Î­Ï†Î±Î½Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î­Ï‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±.
On the peak stands a Nike with spread wings and holding a wreath in her right hand.
á¼…Î¼Î± Î´á½² Ï„Î¿ÏÏ„á¿³ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼¡ á¼Ï€Î¹ÎºÎµÎ¹Î¼Î­Î½Î· Ï„á¿· Ï€Ï…ÏÎ³Î¯á¿³ ÎÎ¯ÎºÎ· ÏƒÏ…Î½ÎµÏ€Î¹ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï†Î®ÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹.
The Nike placed on the small cupola, too, will rotate at the same time with it.
shortQuote: Nike placed on the cupola will rotate at the same time.

name: Animated Woodworkers (Danaans)
source: Book Two, Section XXII.4 (Page 73), Section XXIV (Page 81-83)
purpose: To simulate ship-building construction
agency: The figures perform specific mechanical actions: sawing, hammering, and drilling, accompanied by sound effects.
appearance: Painted figures on the back of the box, but with articulated right arms made of horn. They hold horn tools (axes, hammers, drills).
design: The articulated arms are connected via pegs to a 'hysplÄ“ngion' (a bar mechanism) behind the scene. A star-wheel (asteriskos) rotated by a cord and counterweight strikes the bar repeatedly, causing the arms to move up and down to simulate working.

name: The Thirsty Animal (Pan)
source: Section 29. An Automaton which may be made to drink at any time, on a Liquid being presented to it

name: Hercules and the Dragon
source: Section 40. On an Apple being lifted, Hercules shoots a Dragon which then hisses
purpose: To create a dramatic scene where Hercules shoots a snake that hisses when an apple is stolen.
agency: Hercules reacts to the theft of an apple by shooting an arrow; the dragon reacts to being shot by hissing.
appearance: A pedestal featuring a tree with a coiled dragon/serpent, a figure of Hercules with a bow, and an apple lying on the surface.
design: Lifting the apple pulls a hidden cord that releases a trigger in Hercules' hand, firing the arrow. Simultaneously, lifting the apple opens a water valve; the water displaces air through a whistle, creating the hissing sound.
citations: a small tree round which a serpent or dragon is coiled; a figure of Hercules stands near shooting from a bow, and an apple lies upon the pedestal
if any one raises, with the hand, the apple a little from the pedestal, Hercules shall discharge his arrow at the serpent and the serpent hiss.
he will at the same time raise the cone H, tighten the cord Q W, and draw back the hand, so that the arrow is discharged
shortQuote: Hercules shall discharge his arrow and the serpent hiss

name: The Thirsty Animal (Running Water)
source: Section 28. An Automaton which drinks at certain times only, on a Liquid being presented to it
purpose: To simulate a thirsty animal drinking noisily from a cup offered to it.
agency: The animal waits for a specific moment (indicated by a moving part) to drink greedily when a cup is offered.
appearance: A bronze (or other material) figure of an animal standing on a pedestal.
design: A hidden siphon system creates a vacuum in the pedestal. When the pedestal empties, air is sucked in through the animal's mouth. If a cup of liquid is placed at the mouth during this suction phase, the liquid is drawn in.
citations: make a figure of some animal in bronze or any other material: when a cup is offered to it, the animal shall drink with a loud noise so as to present the appearance of thirst.
Let the mouth of the animal be at R, from which a concealed tube, R S T, must run along one of the feet, or some other part, into the pedestal.
If, then, we apply a drinking vessel at R, the liquid will be violently attracted and sucked down instead of the air
shortQuote: the animal shall drink with a loud noise

name: The Trumpet-Blowing Automaton
source: Section 49. A Trumpet, in the Hands of an Automaton, sounded by compressed Air
purpose: To play a trumpet when air is blown into the bell.
agency: The figure plays the trumpet in response to breath.
appearance: A figure standing on a pedestal holding a trumpet to its mouth.
design: Blowing into the trumpet forces water out of a hemisphere inside the pedestal. When the breath is withdrawn, the water rushes back in, forcing air out through the trumpet's mouthpiece, producing a sound.
citations: A figure stands upon a pedestal having a trumpet in its mouth: if it be blown into, the trumpet shall sound.
From the hemisphere a tube, H F, extends upwards into the figure in the direction of the trumpet
the water will enter the hemisphere again and force out the air, which, passing out through the mouthpiece, will produce the sound of a trumpet.
shortQuote: if it be blown into, the trumpet shall sound

name: The Satyr with the Wine-Skin
source: Section 36. A Satyr pouring Water from a Wine-skin into a full Washing-Basin, without making the contents overflow
purpose: To pour water into a basin that never overflows, despite the continuous supply.
agency: A Satyr pours water from a skin into a basin, seemingly maintaining the water level perfectly.
appearance: A figure of a Satyr holding a wine-skin, standing near a washing basin.
design: An air-tight pedestal is divided into two chambers. As water from the basin flows into one chamber, it displaces air which forces water from the second chamber up through the Satyr's wine-skin and back into the basin, creating a cycle until the supply is exhausted.
citations: Construct on a pedestal the figure of a satyr holding in his hands a wine-skin
water shall be made to flow into the basin without running over, until all the water in the skin is exhausted.
The tube K L M must pass through the mouth of the skin and be particularly fine
shortQuote: water shall flow into the basin without running over

name: The Insatiable Animal
source: Section 30. An Automaton which will drink any quantity that may be presented to it
purpose: To drink an unlimited amount of liquid presented to it.
agency: The animal continuously consumes whatever liquid is placed at its mouth.
appearance: An animal figure standing on a pedestal.
design: A siphon is threaded through the animal's body. When the mouth is dipped into a cup, the external leg of the siphon becomes longer than the internal one, causing the liquid to flow continuously into the pedestal.
citations: The animal may be made to drink without the aid of running water
through the breast and hinder foot or tail of which a tube, E F G, is inserted, leading from the mouth E to the interior of the pedestal.

If, therefore, a drinking vessel be brought to the mouth E, and a portion of the mouth immersed in it, it will be found that the leg of the siphon towards G has become the longer, so that it will attract the water
shortQuote: the leg of the siphon will attract the water

name: The Libation Figures and Hissing Serpent
source: Section 60. Libations poured on an Altar, and a Serpent made to hiss, by the Action of Fire
purpose: To perform religious rites (libations) and sound effects automatically when a fire is lit.
agency: Figures pour wine and a serpent hisses in response to the lighting of a sacrificial fire.
appearance: An altar standing on a pedestal, flanked by figures holding wine vessels/cups and a serpent figure.
design: The heat from the altar fire expands the air within a tube system. This pressure forces wine up from hidden reservoirs through the figures' hands, and forces air through a whistle in the serpent's mouth.
citations: When a fire is kindled on an altar, figures placed near shall offer libations, and a serpent hiss.
The wine flowing through the hands of the figures produces a libation as long as a fire is burning on the altar.
The other tube, conveying the hot air to the mouth of the serpent, will cause the serpent to hiss.
shortQuote: Figures shall offer libations, and a serpent hiss.

name: The Spouting Satyr
source: Section 54. Water driven from the Mouth of a Wine-skin in the Hands of a Satyr, by means of compressed Air
purpose: To create a water jet from a wine-skin held by a statue.
agency: The Satyr sprays water from his wine-skin after air is blown into the pedestal.
appearance: A figure of a Satyr holding a wine-skin, standing on an air-tight pedestal.
design: Air is blown into the pedestal through a tube, compressing the air inside against a volume of water. When a valve is opened, the compressed air forces the water out in a jet through the wine-skin.
citations: if a satyr holds a wine-skin, water shall be spouted up through the skin.
blow in air through the tube E F, the air blown in will thrust aside the plate and descend into the pedestal
the compressed air will drive the liquid in the pedestal violently out through the aperture K
shortQuote: compressed air will drive the liquid violently out

name: The Blowing Figure
source: Section 74. A Steam-Boiler from which a hot-Air blast... is blown into the Fire
purpose: To stoke the fire under a boiler by blowing steam/air onto the coals.
agency: A figure actively blows onto the fire to increase the heat.
appearance: A figure bent downwards, positioned over the coals of a fire, connected to a boiler.
design: Steam generated in a small, high-pressure chamber of the boiler is directed through a tube into the figure's mouth, creating a blast of vapor directed at the coals.
citations: a figure is placed, shaped as if in the act of blowing, the figure shall blow on the coals and thus the boiler be heated
the figure, blowing with great violence, will heat the boiler still higher
the figure must be bent so as to blow downwards
shortQuote: the figure shall blow on the coals

name: Dancing Figures
purpose: To make figures dance or a ball revolve using steam power.
agency: Figures dance in a circle when a fire is lit.
appearance: A group of figures standing on a wheel or platform, often inside a transparent altar of glass or horn.
design: A fire heats water in a boiler/altar. The steam (or hot air) rises through a tube into a pivot mechanism with bent arms (an aeolipile). The reaction force of the escaping steam/air causes the platform holding the figures to rotate.
citations: Place a cauldron over a fire: a ball shall revolve on a pivot.
As the cauldron gets hot it will be found that the steam... causes the ball to revolve, as in the case of the dancing figures.
When a fire is kindled on an altar, figures shall be seen to dance
shortQuote: When a fire is kindled, figures shall dance

name: The Blackbird and Triton
source: Section 75. A Steam-Boiler from which either a hot Blast may be driven into the Fire, a Blackbird made to sing, or a Triton to blow a Horn
purpose: To produce different sounds (birdsong or trumpet) using steam pressure.
agency: A sparrow sings or a Triton blows a trumpet depending on the setting of the machine.
appearance: A boiler surmounted by figures: a sparrow (containing water) and a Triton holding a trumpet.
design: A rotatable tube with holes aligns with different pipes to direct steam. One path leads to a whistle submerged in the sparrow's water body (birdsong); another leads to the Triton's trumpet (horn sound).
citations: On one of these tubes is placed the figure of a sparrow... when the sound of the pipe reaches the water, the note of a blackbird is produced.
a figure shaped like a triton with a trumpet in its mouth... when the vapour reaches these and enters them it will give out the sound of a trumpet.
shortQuote: the note of a blackbird is produced

name: The Decapitated Drinking Animal
source: Section 78. An Automaton, the head of which continues attached to the body, after a knife has entered the neck...
purpose: A magic trick where an animal is beheaded yet remains whole and drinks water.
agency: The animal survives decapitation and immediately drinks water.
appearance: A figure of an animal standing on a pedestal.
design: A complex system of toothed wheels and sliding cylinders allows a knife to pass through the neck without severing the internal connection. Once the knife passes, the internal tubes realign, and a siphon system (triggered by a rotating herdsman figure) creates suction to make the animal drink.
citations: An animal shall be made to drink while it is being severed in two.
the head of the animal adhere to the neck.
When the knife has passed quite through the neck... let water be offered to the animal... the current of air caused by the stream of water will attract the water offered to the mouth of the animal.
shortQuote: An animal shall drink while it is being severed.

name: The Revolving Black-Cap
source: Section 68. A Shrine over which a Bird may be made to revolve and sing by Worshippers turning a Wheel

design: Turning the entrance wheel winds a cord that lifts a conical vessel. When released, the vessel descends into water, forcing air through a whistle to make the bird sing. Gears connect the main wheel to the bird's axis, causing it to rotate.
citations: if the wheel is turned, the note of the black-cap shall be produced, and the bird, standing on the top of the shrine, turn round as well
The black-cap turns round at the same time owing to the revolution of the wheels.
shortQuote: the note of the black-cap shall be produced

name: Yen-shih's Performer
source: Chapter 5: The Questions of T'ang (Section: King Mu of Chou and the Craftsman Yen-shih)

design: It is an intricate mechanical construct made of leather, wood, glue, and lacquer. It contains artificial internal organs (heart, liver, kidneys, etc.) and external features (muscles, bones, joints) that function interdependently; removing the heart stops speech, removing the liver stops sight, and removing the kidneys stops movement.

When the craftsman pushed its cheek it sang in tune; when he clasped its hand it danced in time; it did innumerable tricks, whatever it pleased you to ask.
When the entertainment was about to end, the performer winked his eye and beckoned to the concubines in waiting on the King's left and right.
It was all made by sticking together leather, wood, glue and lacquer, coloured white, black, red and blue.

On the inside the liver, gall, heart, lungs, spleen, kidneys, intestines and stomach, on the outside the muscles, bones, limbs, joints, skin, teeth and hair, were all artificial, but complete without exception.
shortQuote: it did innumerable tricks, whatever it pleased you to ask

name: The Pan and The Fearful Animal

when the figure is turned towards the animal, it shall not drink, as though frightened; when the figure turns away, it shall drink.
